conclusion: The problem involves determining the velocity \( v_0 \) of block \( a \) immediately after its collision with block \( b \).
Block \( b \) is released from a height \( h = 1.25 \) m, and its potential energy is converted to kinetic energy at the bottom.
Using conservation of energy, the velocity of block \( b \) just before the collision is calculated as \( v_b = 5 \, \text{m/s} \).
Block \( a \) is initially at rest at point \( A \), and the collision between blocks \( a \) and \( b \) is elastic.
Using conservation of momentum and kinetic energy, the velocity of block \( a \) just before the collision is derived as \( v_a = \frac{5\sqrt{2}}{2} \, \text{m/s} \).
After the collision, block \( a \) has a velocity \( v_a = \frac{5\sqrt{2}}{2} \, \text{m/s} \).
Block \( a \) slides on the conveyor belt, which has a coefficient of kinetic friction \( \mu = 0.5 \).
The frictional force acting on block \( a \) is \( F_f = 10 \, \text{N} \), and the acceleration due to friction is \( a = 5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
The time for block \( a \) to come to rest on the conveyor belt is \( t = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \, \text{s} \).
